pullRequest.title: [FLINK-14356][table][formats] Introduce "raw" format to (de)serialize message to a single field
pullRequest.bodyText:
What is the purpose of the change
This is a code improvement based on #11896.
This pull request introduct single-field format to (de)serialize message to a single field.
Brief change log
Modifications based on  #11896:

Rename format from single-value to single-field, because it's more literal that it's used for single field/column. And personally, 'value.format' = 'single-field' is better than 'value.format' = 'single-value' when it's used in Kafka connector. KSQL also has a similar feature for single field (un)wrapping.
Move clases to flink-table-runtime-blink for easy testing.
Using Flink's primitive TypeSerializers for encoding/decoding primitive values.
Encode null values as null byte[]. This may have limitation when used in upsert-kafka, because upsert-kafka treats null values as a tombstone message. Therefore, we recommend avoiding using upsert-kafka connector and single-field format if the field can have a null value. KSQL also has this limitation.

Verifying this change

SingleFieldFormatFactoryTest for verifing format factory
SingleFieldSerDeSchemaTest for verifying serializing and deserializing values with different types.

@@ -0,0 +1,151 @@ +--- +title: "Single Field Format" +nav-title: SingleField +nav-parent_id: sql-formats +nav-pos: 7 +--- + + +Format: Serialization Schema +Format: Deserialization Schema + +* This will be replaced by the TOC +{:toc} + +The SingleField format allows to read and write data where the data contains only a single field, and that field is not wrapped within a JSON object, or an Avro record. + +Currently, the SingleField format supports `String`, `byte[]` and primitive type. + +Note: this format encodes `null` values as `null` `byte[]`. This may have limitation when used in `upsert-kafka`, because `upsert-kafka` treats `null` values as a tombstone message (DELETE on the key). Therefore, we recommend avoiding using `upsert-kafka` connector and `single-field` format if the field can have a `null` value. + +Example +---------------- + +For example, you may have following raw log data in Kafka and want to read and analyse such data using Flink SQL. + +``` +47.29.201.179 - - [28/Feb/2019:13:17:10 +0000] "GET /?p=1 HTTP/2.0" 200 5316 "https://domain.com/?p=1" "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/72.0.3626.119 Safari/537.36" "2.75" +``` + +The following creates a table where it reads from (and writes to) the underlying Kafka topic as an anonymous string value by using `single-field` format: + +
+
+{% highlight sql %} +CREATE TABLE nginx_log ( + log STRING +) WITH ( + 'connector' = 'kafka', + 'topic' = 'nginx_log', + 'properties.bootstrap.servers' = 'localhost:9092', + 'properties.group.id' = 'testGroup', + 'format' = 'single-field' +) +{% endhighlight %} +
+
+ +Then you can read out the raw data as a pure string, and split it into multiple fields using user-defined-function for further analysing, e.g. `my_split` in the example. + +
+
+{% highlight sql %} +SELECT t.hostname, t.datetime, t.url, t.browser, ... +FROM( + SELECT my_split(log) as t FROM nginx_log +); +{% endhighlight %} +
+
+ +In contrast, you can also write a single field of STRING type into Kafka topic as an anonymous string value. + +Format Options +---------------- + + + + + + + + + + + + + +
OptionRequiredDefaultTypeDescription
format

nodes.bodyText:
nit: call thisproducedTypeInfo for consistency
final?
Would we have a performance benefit of implementing the deserialization logic ourselves? instead of setting fields and delegating to other classes.
Same comment as before, this looks overly complicated to just convert a a couple of data types to bytes. We should think about doing it manually.
Is this Flink's representation of strings in bytes? I could imagine that most people assume "string".getBytes() semantics. Is the string length included in the bytes are as well?
can't we use RawValueData.fromBytes here and do lazy deserialization?
nit: Defines the endianness for bytes of numeric values.
shall we perform real type validation here? e.g. TIMESTAMP or NULL would still pass
I think data is never null at this location.
